Nos joyeux bricolos soiffards seront Philippe, Thierry, Louis, et vous ici public chÃ©ri. Nous serons rÃ©unis autour dâ€™un verre, pour faire le point sur ce sujet complexe et controversÃ©.
Nous vous proposerons un tour matÃ©riel et SDK et langages pour que chacun puisse repartir en ayant des envies et des idÃ©es de projets Ã tester ou rÃ©aliser.

column.name: title

Pour les petites applications, le nombre dâ€™environnements va Ãªtre limitÃ©, mais lorsque lâ€™on souhaite mettre en place du Blue-Green Deployment ou du Canary Release, ce nombre va subitement grimper.
A cela on rajoute : une architecture distribuÃ©e, le paramÃ©trage de lâ€™infrastructure et des composants pour chaque environnement, et lâ€™on arrive rapidement Ã devoir gÃ©rer des centaines de paramÃ¨tres sur des dizaines dâ€™environnements.

Je vous propose durant ce talk de comprendre comment on arrive rapidement sur ces problÃ©matiques. Puis, je vous prÃ©senterai un ensemble de bonnes pratiques et dâ€™astuces pour Ã©viter lâ€™enfer !

column.name: title
column.value: How To Review Someone's Code While Not Being A Jerk!

column.name: description
column.value:
Most of us do code reviews very often if not daily. However, how can we tell whether we are good reviewers or not? Do we review a code as robots? Do we keep in mind that we are reviewing the code of someone who invested time and knowledge to write this code, and thus deserves to get respectful feedback?
In this talk, we present the code review best practices and we answer the following questions: What to look for in a code review? How can we write useful reviews?
Furthermore, we explain the key tips for writing respectful and constructive code review feedback. To discover more about all these points and more, come and see our talk.

column.name: title

En sâ€™appuyant sur le DDD, nous avons donc crÃ©Ã© Candy-Doc, un projet open-source, pour extraire de notre base de code, les concepts mÃ©tiers de notre logiciel pour en faire une documentation fonctionnelle Ã part entiÃ¨re.

column.name: title
column.value: Â« Je ne suis pas sysadmin mais je veux faire de la CI/CD Â»

column.name: description
column.value:
Code#0 (pronounced Code First) is a free and open-source infrastructure to allow conception, development, tests and deployment cross-platforms (Linux, MacOSX, Windows, Android, iOS), cross-languages (C++, Java, C#, PHP, Javascript, Ruby, RUST, Go, Python, Dartâ€¦) and mutli-targets (stores, web, desktop, mobile, plugin, container, REST APIâ€¦), based on opensource tools (gitea, drone, sonarqube, docker, traefik, swaggerâ€¦). It focuses on universities and small companies. Its main goals, for universities, are:
to guide sys/admin teams through the setup and the configuration of this infrastructure, to provide a pedagogical infrastructure to teachers and professors to help them manage practical projects with tutorials and guides to bring students the possibility to use professional tools, good practices in development, project management and team work. But as mentioned earlier, it will also benefit small (or even medium) companies with a usable infrastructure for their professional projects.

column.name: title

column.name: title
column.value: Mutation Testing - Did my test break my code ? ðŸ¤”

column.name: description
column.value:
Last week, you spend the last 2 days writing plenty of tests. Your code coverage was 100% so you thought you could safely leave on a weekend âœˆï¸ðŸ–ï¸
But on Monday, your inbox is flooded with new bug reports. What happened!? What did you miss?
In this talk, we present Mutation testing which is a technique to evaluate the quality of tests beyond the number of lines tested. Mutation testing is based on creating a changed copy of the code to ensure a software test suite is able to detect the changes.
How do we create Mutation tests? How does it work? What are the advantages and drawbacks of Mutation tests? All these questions will be answered with a demo in this talk.
Come and discover what Mutation testing is and how can we implement it to ensure the quality of our test suites.

column.name: title

I discovered Go language but didnâ€™t have any time to follow multiples tutorials to learn it. But one day I discovered TrÃ¦fik reverse-proxy project when I wanted to switch my infrastructure into fully dockerized one. Then I decided to write my own TrÃ¦fik cache system, but the main question was â€œWhich language?â€
PHP ? Nah. Nodejs ? What a joke ! C++ ? I didnâ€™t learn this language at school and itâ€™s really insane to learn. Then I was on TrÃ¦fik github repository when I decided to write it in Go. Another good point: thatâ€™s compatible with docker integration.

column.name: title
column.value: Du code SOLID comme un rock, câ€™est vraiment utile ?

column.name: description
column.value:
En informatique, plus prÃ©cisÃ©ment en programmation orientÃ©e objet, on entend souvent parler de programmation SOLID.
SOLID câ€™est un acronyme de 5 principes qui sont censÃ©s nous permettre dâ€™avoir une architecture logicielle plus comprÃ©hensible et maintenable. Câ€™est ce bon vieux Martin dans lâ€™article Design Principles and Design Patterns de 2000 qui Ã©voque ces principes. (Ca fait donc dÃ©jÃ 20 ans quâ€™on en parleâ€¦)
Mais dans la vraie vue, est-ce que ce nâ€™est pas surtout beaucoup de boulot pour pas grand-chose ? Dans quelles situations SOLID est vraiment intÃ©ressant ? Est-ce que cela sert vraiment ?
AprÃ¨s avoir revu les bases du principe de SOLID, nous verrons ensemble, pour chacun des principes, un cas trÃ¨s imagÃ© de lâ€™avantage quâ€™il procure, et dans quelle situation ce principe sâ€™avÃ¨re utile.

Je vous propose de monter sur le ring et de mettre face Ã face SwiftUI Ã ma droite et Jetpack Compose Ã ma gauche. Nous allons comparer leur design, leur usage, leurs diffÃ©rences et leurs perspectives pour avoir un vainqueur et voir qui remporte ce match.

column.name: title
column.value: Le mot de la fin
